c:complexType.name: ChartCommonOptions
c:complexType.c:documentation: The common options documentation class of all charts.

c:property.name: title
c:property.c:documentation:
The title panel of the root chart.
When a value of type string is specified, it is the title text.

c:property.name: legend
c:property.c:documentation:
The legend panel of the root chart.
When a value of type boolean is specified, it indicates the visibility of the legend. The default is false.

c:property.name: visualRoles
c:property.c:documentation: The visual roles that are common to all chart types.

c:property.name: canvas
c:property.c:documentation:
The identifier of the HTML element, or the element itself, where the chart is to be created in.
The chart element will be a child of the canvas element.
When unspecified, the chart element will be added as the last child of the HTML document body.

c:property.name: compatVersion
c:property.c:documentation:
The CCC version that the chart should run in.
The value 1 emulates version 1 of CCC.

c:property.name: width
c:property.c:documentation: The width of the root chart, in pixels.

c:property.name: height
c:property.c:documentation: The height of the root chart, in pixels.

c:property.name: orientation
c:property.c:documentation:
The chart orientation indicates if its main direction is vertical or horizontal.
This property is supported by most chart types.

c:property.name: margins
c:property.c:documentation:
The margins of the root chart.
In a small multiples chart, the margins of the small charts can be set with the property .
See for information about the different supported data types.

c:property.name: paddings
c:property.c:documentation:
The paddings of root chart.
In a small multiples chart, the paddings of a small chart can be set with the property .
See for information about the different supported data types.

c:property.name: contentMargins
c:property.c:documentation:
The margins of the root content panel.
In a small multiples chart, the margins of the content panel of a small chart can be set with the property .
See for information about the different supported data types.

c:property.name: contentPaddings
c:property.c:documentation:
The paddings of the root content panel.
In a small multiples chart, the paddings of the content panel of a small chart can be set with the property .
See for information about the different supported data types.

c:property.name: animate
c:property.c:documentation:
Indicates if a chart should show an entry animation, every time it is fully rendered. Most charts perform some sort of entry animation of its main visual elements.
When a chart is rendered explicitly, through its render method, it is possible to control whether the entry animation is performed or not.

c:property.name: clickable
c:property.c:documentation:
Indicates if the chart is clickable by the user.
If this option is false, any click-related actions will not be executed (ex: , , or ).

c:property.name: hoverable
c:property.c:documentation: Indicates if the chart's visual elements are automatically highlighted when the user hovers over them with the mouse.

c:property.name: selectable
c:property.c:documentation: Indicates if the chart's visual elements can be selected by the user, by clicking on them or using the rubber-band.

c:property.name: showTooltips
c:property.c:documentation: Indicates if tooltips are shown when the user hovers over visual elements with the mouse.

c:property.name: ctrlSelectMode
c:property.c:documentation:
When true, indicates that a selection made by the user replaces the current selection, if any.
For the selection to be additive, the CTRL key must be pressed, by the end of the operation.
When false, indicates that any selection made by the user is additive. The CTRL key has no effect.

c:property.name: clearSelectionMode
c:property.c:documentation: Controls if and how the selection can be cleared by the user.

c:property.name: doubleClickMaxDelay
c:property.c:documentation: The maximum number of milliseconds, between two consecutive clicks, for them to be considered a double-click.

c:property.name: tooltipFormat
c:property.c:documentation:
A callback function that is called, to build the tooltip of a visual element.
Whether the tooltip format is HTML or plain text must be known by the formatter.

c:property.name: tipsySettings
c:property.c:documentation: Contains tooltip presentation options.

c:property.name: renderCallback
c:property.c:documentation:
A callback function that is called before the chart is rendered, but after if has been pre-rendered.
You can use this action to:
use the mark events API on time-series categorical charts
extend in special ways the already created protovis marks.

c:property.name: clickAction
c:property.c:documentation: A callback function that is called when the user clicks on a visual element.

c:property.name: doubleClickAction
c:property.c:documentation: A callback function that is called when the user double-clicks on a visual element.

c:property.name: selectionChangedAction
c:property.c:documentation: A callback function that is called when, after selection has changed, the chart is updated to reflect the change.

c:property.name: userSelectionAction
c:property.c:documentation:
A callback function that is called when the user performs a selection, but before the corresponding datums' selected state are actually changed.
This function is usefull to restrict, amplify, or normalize the selection.

c:property.name: ignoreNulls
c:property.c:documentation:
Indicates if datums whose value of all measure dimensions is null should be ignored.
A dimension is considered a measure dimension if there is at least one measure role currently bound to it.

c:property.name: timeSeries
c:property.c:documentation:
Indicates that dimensions of the "category" group (i.e. named category, category2, ...) have a Date value type, by default.
This option has no effect on other dimensions, even if bound to a "category" visual role. In those cases, explicitly define the dimension with the Date value type.
Dimensions are considered continuous, by default, when they have a continuous value type. However, not all visual roles support continuous dimensions. In those cases, the dimension is treated as a discrete dimension, event though it has a continuous value type.

c:property.name: timeSeriesFormat
c:property.c:documentation:
The format string used by default to parse dimensions of the Date value type.
The syntax of the format string is that of protovis' date formats.
This property changes the default of the
property, for dimensions with a Date value type.

c:property.name: groupedLabelSep
c:property.c:documentation:
The separator used to join the labels of the values of a multi-dimensional visual role.
For example, if a visual role, has the dimensions "Territory" and "ProductType", a compound value could be shown as "EMEA ~ Classic Cars".

c:property.name: valueFormat
c:property.c:documentation:
A function that formats the non-null numeric values of the dimensions named value, value2, etc.
This property is used to default the property
of the mentioned dimensions.
The default value of this option is a function that formats numbers with two decimal places.

c:property.name: percentValueFormat
c:property.c:documentation:
A function used to format non-null numeric values as percentages.
The numeric value has still to be multiplied by 100.
This function is used whenever a chart needs to show percentages of a numeric dimension, like is the case for the tooltips of a stacked chart or the percentages shown in a Pie chart.
The default value of this option is a function that formats percentages with one decimal place and a "%" character suffix.

c:property.name: dimensions
c:property.c:documentation:
A map whose keys are the dimension type names and whose values are the dimension type options.
You don't need to define dimensions unless you want to change their name or properties. Charts automatically define default dimensions to satisfy their visual roles' requirements.
Dimension options can be partial, so that it is possible to override only certain options.

c:property.name: dimensionGroups
c:property.c:documentation:
A map whose keys are the dimension type group names and whose values are the default dimension type group options.
A dimension type group is a group of dimension types that have a common non-numeric prefix in its name.
This property does not define any dimension types, per si, but allows specifying default values for dimension types of a group, that apply in case they are effectively used.

c:property.name: crosstabMode
c:property.c:documentation: Indicates if the data source is in crosstab format.

c:property.name: seriesInRows
c:property.c:documentation:
Indicates if, in the data source, the "series" data is in the rows, instead of, as is more usual, in the columns.
The name of this option is inspired in the crosstab format, where the "series" values are placed in the first row, and "category" values are placed in the first column (corner cell is empty).
When this option is true, in the crosstab format, the result is equivalent to transposing the data table, which results in "series" data being placed in the first column, i.e. in the rows, and the "category" data being placed in the first row.
In the relational data source format, this option effects a conceptually equivalent operation, by switching the "series" and "category" columns.

c:property.name: isMultiValued
c:property.c:documentation: Indicates if the data source has multiple value dimensions.

c:property.name: measuresIndexes
c:property.c:documentation:
The indexes of the data source's virtual item columns that are to feed the default value, value2, ... dimensions.
This option only applies to data sources in relational format with multiple values, i.e., when crosstabMode=false and isMultiValued=true.

c:property.name: readers
c:property.c:documentation:
An array of dimensions readers.
Can be specified to customize the translation process of the data source.

c:property.name: calculations
c:property.c:documentation:
An array of dimensions calculations.
Can be specified to calculate the values of certain dimensions.

c:property.name: colors
c:property.c:documentation:
The discrete colors scheme to use to distinguish visual elements that are colored using the first color axis.
With a few exceptions, color axes map values of the "color" visual role.

c:complexType.name: ChartCommonVisualRoles
c:complexType.c:documentation: The visual roles common to all chart types.

c:complexType.name: ChartCommonExtensionPoints
c:complexType.c:documentation:
The extension points common to all chart types.
To use an extension point you must find its full name: join the prefix property name, like , with one of the properties of the type of the extension point, like , with an "_" character in between, and obtain the name base_overflow.

c:property.name: base
c:property.c:documentation: The extension point of the base (root) panel of the root chart.

c:property.name: content
c:property.c:documentation:
The extension point of the content panel of the root chart.
The content panel is a child of the base panel.

c:property.name: plot
c:property.c:documentation:
The extension point of the plot panel of the charts.
The plot panel is a child of the content panel.
The root of a small multiples chart does not have a plot panel.

c:property.name: chart
c:property.c:documentation:
Use the extension point instead. The extension point of the plot panel of the charts.
The plot panel is a child of the content panel.

c:property.name: rubberBand
c:property.c:documentation: The extension point of the selection rubber-band.

c:complexType.name: TooltipOptions
c:complexType.c:documentation: The options documentation class of the tooltip.

c:complexType.name: DimensionTypeOptions
c:complexType.c:documentation: The options documentation class of a dimension type.

c:property.name: label
c:property.c:documentation:
The name of the dimension type as it is shown to the user.
The label should be unique.
The default value is built from the dimension name, by converting the first character to upper case.

c:property.name: valueType
c:property.c:documentation: The type of value that dimensions of this type will hold.

c:property.name: isDiscrete
c:property.c:documentation:
Indicates if a dimension type should be considered discrete or continuous.
Only dimension types whose is one of or
can be continuous.
Some chart types support binding a continuous or a discrete dimension to a visual role, yielding different visual results. An example is the "color" visual role of the Metric Line/Dot charts. Another example is the Line/Dot/Area chart that supports both a continuous or a discrete dimension in its "category" visual role.
The default value dependends on the value of . If it can be continuous, then the default value is false. If it cannot, the default value is true.

c:property.name: converter
c:property.c:documentation:
Converts a non-null raw value, as read from the data source, into a value of the dimension's .
The returned value need not have the type of the dimension's value type. Yet, it must be such that the associated value type's cast function can convert it to the dimension's value type. In this way, only "non-standard" conversions need to be handled with a converter function.
Values that are not convertible by the dimension's value type cast function become null.
Also, note that the only value type that does not have a cast function is the .
When unspecified and the value type is , and the option is specified a default converter is created for it.

c:property.name: rawFormat
c:property.c:documentation:
A protovis format string that is to parse the raw value.
Currently, this option is ignored unless the option is unspecified and the value type is .
When the chart option , is specified, and the value type is , it is taken as the default value of this option.
A converter function is created to parse raw values with the specified format string.

c:property.name: key
c:property.c:documentation:
A function that converts a non-null value of the dimension's
into a string that (uniquely) identifies the value in the dimension.
The default key function is the standard JavaScript String function, and is suitable for most value types.
If the dimension's value type is one of or
the String function may not be suitable to identify the values.
If more than one value has a given key, only the first one will be stored in the dimension.

c:property.name: comparer
c:property.c:documentation:
A function that compares two different and non-null values of the dimension's .
When unspecified, a default natural order comparer function is applied to the continuous value types: and .
Dimension types that do not have a comparer function "compare" their values by "input order" - order of first appearance, in the data source.

c:property.name: formatter
c:property.c:documentation:
A function that formats a value, possibly null, of the dimension's .
Note that, the chart option , is used to build a default formatter function for numeric dimensions of the "value" dimension group.
When unspecified and the value type is , a default formatter is created that formats numbers with two decimal places.
When unspecified and the value type is , and the option is specified (or implied) a default formatter is created for it.
Otherwise a value is formatted by calling the standard JavaScript String function on it.

c:property.name: format
c:property.c:documentation:
A protovis format string that is to format a value of the dimension's .
Currently, this option is ignored unless the option is unspecified and the value type is .
When unspecified, but the option is specified, a format string is created from the later (simply by replacing "-" with "/").
A formatter function is created to format values with the specified or implied format string.

c:property.name: isHidden
c:property.c:documentation:
Indicates if values of this dimension type should be hidden from the user.
This option is useful to hide auxiliar dimensions that are used to:
hold extra data, required for drill-down purposes
complete the minimal working information a chart needs to work, like, for example, a "series" dimension created automatically by a chart if its required "series" visual role was not unbound
The only place where the values of a dimension that is not bound to a visual role are shown to the user is the tooltip, as it is formatted by default. To prevent this, set the dimension type's isHidden option to true.

c:complexType.name: DimensionsCalculationOptions
c:complexType.c:documentation:
A dimensions calculation allows the values of a dimension to be calculated from the typed values of the other non-calculated dimensions.
While a dimensions reader could achieve the same result, it works by reading values from the virtual item, accessing it by index. That would require the knowledge of the indexes in which the desired dimensions were, which is many times not true, specially when the mapping between dimensions and virtual item indexes is determined automatically by the data translator.

c:property.name: names
c:property.c:documentation:
The name or names of the dimensions that are calculated by the calculation.
When the argument is a string, it can be a list of names, separated by the character ",".
Only one dimensions calculation or dimensions reader can calculate or read a given dimension.

c:property.name: calculation
c:property.c:documentation: A dimensions calculation function.

c:complexType.name: DimensionsReaderOptions
c:complexType.c:documentation:
The options documentation class of a data dimensions reader.
A dimensions reader is executed for each row of a data source to convert values of one or more columns into one or more atoms of certain dimensions.
Together, a set of dimensions readers, are executed to fully convert each data source row into atoms of the defined dimension types. The atoms of each row are used to construct a datum.
The mentioned data source row is called the "virtual item". Depending on the data source format the actual rows carry different informaton. The virtual item is a normalized view of each row of the data source, independent of its format.
A dimensions reader can be configured in the following ways:
specify names but not reader
names are paired with any specified indexes, from left to right; excess indexes feed dimensions whose name starts with the last specified name (a dimension group); excess names are fed with the non reservedindexes that follow the last specified index (or 0, if none); indexes explicitly specified in dimensions readers are all reserved beforehand
specify indexes but not names and reader
the specified indexes become reserved but are not read, and so are effectively ignored
specify both reader and names
any specified indexes are reserved, and no pairing is performed between these and the specified names; the reader function may read any cell from the virtual item and return atoms from any of the dimensions specified in names; atoms of stated dimensions, that are not returned, result in a null value; this form allows, for example, splitting a value in the virtual item into two dimensions.

c:property.name: names
c:property.c:documentation:
The name or names of the dimensions that the reader reads from each virtual item.
When the argument is a string, it can be a list of names, separated by the character ",".
Only one dimensions reader or dimensions calculation can read or calculate a given dimension.

c:property.name: indexes
c:property.c:documentation:
The index or indexes, of each virtual item, that are to be read.
Only one dimensions reader can state that it reads a given index (although a dimensions reader function may read any cells, stated or not).

c:property.name: reader
c:property.c:documentation:
A dimensions reader function, reads values mapped to dimensions from a virtual item row.
When unspecified, one is created that performs a simple mapping between the specified names and indexes.
A dimensions reader function can be specified to perform non-simple operations over the read cells, like the following:
combine values from two or more cells into a single dimension,
split the value of one cell into more than one dimension,
feed a dimension with correlated data read from an external data source.
Dimensions reader functions need not be specifed to perform conversion or formatting operations of a single cell. For those cases, the dimension type's
and
are more appropriate.
Also, when the value of a dimension is calculated from the value of other dimensions, a dimensions calculation may be more appropriate: see .
The function may read cells whose indexes were not "reserved" in indexes. Those cells might be read by other readers, possibly default ones created by the translator.

c:complexType.name: PlotCommonOptions
c:complexType.c:documentation: The common options documentation class of all plots.

c:property.name: valuesVisible
c:property.c:documentation:
Indicates if value labels are shown next to the visual elements.
Most charts have some form of showing labels with the main value next to the visual element.
The default value really varies with the chart type, so be sure to confirm it in the most specific plot class.

c:property.name: showValues
c:property.c:documentation: Use instead. Indicates if value labels are shown next to the visual elements.

c:property.name: valuesAnchor
c:property.c:documentation:
The alignment of a value label relative to its corresponding visual element position.
The possible values and the default value actually depend on the chart type so be sure to access this property's documentation through the concrete class' documentation.

c:property.name: valuesFont
c:property.c:documentation:
The font of a value label.
This property can also be specified through the "label" extension point of a plot.
In some charts the value label font is taken into account for layout purposes.

c:property.name: colorAxis
c:property.c:documentation:
The index of the color axis to use for the plot.
The possible values are 1, 2 and 3.
The default value depends on the plot. The main plot of a chart always uses the axis 1. The plot2 plot uses the axis 2, by default. The trend plot uses the axis 3, by default.

c:property.name: extensionPoints
c:property.c:documentation: The extension points object contains style definitions for the marks of the chart.
